primary_factors: Low forecast snowfall (~1.1") concentrated 2–4 AM; Michigan tolerance is high for 1–3" events
Plow-timing window exists: ~2.7–3.7 hours from snow end (~04:00–05:00) to first bell (~07:40), typically enough for primary roads
Main risk is refreeze/black ice (temps fall into teens; prior icing reports in the area), affecting bridges, shaded roads, parking lots, and secondary/rural routes
No confirmed neighboring-district closures/delays found as of Wed afternoon; weak real-time “closure signal” from local district pages/calendars
Wind chills near/just below 0°F are uncomfortable but not in the typical auto-closure range for Kent County
decision_rationale:
PRE-DECISION CHECKLIST
1) Agreement across experts: All four sources converge that new snow for Thu morning is light (~1") and mainly pre-dawn (around 2–4 AM). Everyone flags that the bigger hazard is patchy slickness/refreeze rather than deep snow or a true whiteout. 
2) Disagreements/conflicts: News coverage emphasizes “dangerous wind chills/continued lake-effect,” which could imply higher disruption; Meteorology clarifies this isn’t contradictory—wind chills are harsh but the point forecast keeps meaningful snowfall out of the Thu morning commute (evening is more problematic). Safety/Historical upgrade the ICE/refreeze pathway versus the raw snow-total pathway.
3) Plow timing math: Snow ends ~04:00–05:00; school start ~07:40 → ~2.7–3.7 hours. Safety analyst notes primaries often recover in ~1–2 hours post-snow; secondaries can take ~2–4 hours and remain variable at 07:40.
4) Any ice? Yes, at least a meaningful refreeze/black-ice risk. Safety upgraded ice risk to HIGH due to falling temps and recent icing signals; meteorologist says freezing drizzle isn’t expected Thu AM, but residual moisture/slush can refreeze.
5) Neighboring districts: News intel check found NO confirmed Thu 1/22 closures/delays posted on Rockford, Sparta, Cedar Springs, Northview, or Greenville surfaced pages; no “3+ neighboring districts closed” trigger.
6) What would make me wrong? (a) A lake-effect band shifts inland earlier than forecast and drops several inches near dawn, reducing the plow window effectiveness; (b) widespread black ice/glazing is reported on bus routes pre-6 AM; (c) an overnight crash spike/official road advisory emerges.

WEIGHTED SYNTHESIS (per directive):
- Meteorology (35%): points to light snow ending before commute; low snow-day signal.
- Safety (25%): moderate morning commute impact; refreeze risk could justify a delay in rural pockets but not a strong closure case.
- History (20%): similar setups skew OPEN or DELAY; closures uncommon (~5–10%) unless widespread glazing is confirmed.
- News intel (20%): no confirmed neighboring closures; some recent severe icing chatter raises caution but not enough for a closure call without current/official confirmation.

Bottom line: With only ~1" new snow and a workable plow window, a full snow day is unlikely; the main credible impact is patchy black ice on secondary roads and lots. I’m setting a 14% snow-day probability (closure), with the more likely operational outcome being “open” or a short delay if early-morning road checks look poor on rural routes.
